segments.key_quote: Krishna's topics are so relishable that you go on hearing and you never become saturated.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam 1.18.14, emphasizing the inexhaustible nature of Krishna's topics and the unending satisfaction derived from hearing about Him.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 14th verse of the 18th chapter, the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Konama Tripyet Rasavit Kathayam Mahattamayikanta Parayanasya Nantam Gunanam Agunasya Jagmahu Yogeshwaraye Bhavapadma Mukhyaha. The meaning of this verse is, the Personality of God, the Personality of God and Lord Krishna, Govinda, is the exclusive shelter for all great living beings, and his transcendental attributes cannot even be measured by such masters of mystic powers as Lord Shiva and Lord Brahma. Can anyone who is expert in relishing nectar or rasa ever be fully satiated by hearing topics about him? This is spoken by the sages of Naimisha Araniyata Sutakoswami. Shri Krishna's disciples always tell us that Krishna's topics are so relishable that you go on hearing and you never become saturated. That means you never feel enough. I can't take anymore, I can't relish anymore.

segments.key_quote: There is something about it which is different from all material songs material song vibrations so the topics about Krishna are like that you will never get saturated you never
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts material experiences, which lead to saturation, with the unending satisfaction derived from chanting the Hare Krishna mantra and hearing about Krishna.
segments.transcript: No! It never happens. We have material experience. Anything which is very nice to eat or drink or anything which is light to the soul, meaning extremely goodigmatism, is nice to hear. Some material music, if it is very pleasing to hear the first time, then you may want to hear a second time. You hear a second time, then you may say, 'Oh, it's nice, I want to hear a third time.' How many times can you keep on hearing the same thing again and again and again? You cannot hear too many times. At a certain point, it becomes boring. You cannot hear any, it becomes saturated. The Hare Krishna mantra, on the other hand, devotees have been chanting for 10 years, 20 years, some devotees for 30 years. I've been chanting for 32 years. There are devotees who have been chanting for 50 years, 40 years. They never get saturated or satiated, they never get bored. So what is it about the Hare Krishna mantra that we go on singing, we go on hearing, we go on chanting, and we don't get bored or we don't get saturated? There is something about it which is different from all material songs, material...

segments.key_quote: Lord Shiva drank an ocean of poison of which one drop was sufficient to kill an ordinary living being
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Lord Shiva drinking the ocean of poison to illustrate his immense mystic power, as an example of the powers that even great demigods possess.

So that poison is a deadly poison, and it was unbearable for both the Devatas and the Asuras. So what to do with this poison now? So they requested Lord Shiva, 'Do something.' Shiva said, 'I don't know what to do with this poison now.' So they requested Lord Shiva, 'Do something.' Shiva said, 'Don't worry,' he just took the whole quantity of poison and just condensed it into one sip in his hand, and he just drank it off. segments.key_quote: Suta Goswami is eager to speak and the sages are eager to hear so this is the perfect ideal combination
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by highlighting the eagerness of both Suta Goswami to speak and the sages of Naimisaranya to hear about Krishna, creating a perfect environment for spiritual discourse.
segments.transcript: this Suta Goswami, knowing this fact, he desired to continue the topics of Lord Krishna before the series name is Aranya, and the sages of name is Aranya also, they wholeheartedly agreed for this proposal. If you remember, in the end of the third chapter, the first canto, Suta Goswami completed answering six questions the sage Vamisharanya asked in the beginning of this Bhagavatam, and after finishing, he did not say, 'Now whatever you asked, I've answered, that's it, over, finished.' No, he completed answering, and he himself said, Suta Goswami said, 'Seeing your eagerness to hear about Krishna, I am now going to narrate to you the Srimad Bhagavatam which I heard from Shukadeva Goswami when Shukadeva Goswami is speaking to Parikshitmar.' So Suta Goswami is ready to recite, but what about the sages? Do they want to hear? Yes, they are telling, 'Kindly speak more, more and more and more, we are never saturated by hearing, there is no boredom, there is no satiation, so kindly go on speaking.' So both are like, Suta Goswami is eager to speak, and the sages are eager to hear. So this is the perfect ideal combination. I'll stop here, thank you very much.
